Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Open Gateway Computing Environments Science Gateways Platform as a Service (OGCE SciGaP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science Gateways are virtual environments that dramatically accelerate scientific discovery by enabling scientific communities to utilize distributed computational and data resources (that is, cyberinfrastructure). Successful Science Gateways provide access to sophisticated and powerful resources, while shielding their users from the resources' complexities. Given Science Gateways' demonstrated impact on progress in many scientific fields, it is important to remove barriers to the creation of new gateways and make it easier to sustain them. The Science Gateway Platform (SciGaP) project will create a set of hosted infrastructure services that can be easily adopted by gateway providers to build new gateways based on robust and reliable open source tools. The proposed work will transform the way Science Gateways are constructed by significantly lowering the development overhead for communities requiring access to cyberinfrastructure, and support the efficient utilization of shared resources.

SciGaP will transform access to large scale computing and data resources by reducing development time of new gateways and by accelerating scientific research for communities in need of access to large-scale resources. SciGaP's adherence to open community and open governance principles of the Apache Software Foundation will assure open source software access and open operation of its services. This will give all project stakeholders a voice in the software and will clear the proprietary fog that surrounds cyberinfrastructure services. The benefits of SciGaP services are not restricted to scientific fields, but can be used to accelerate progress in any field of endeavor that is limited by access to computational resources. SciGaP services will be usable by a community of any size, whether it is an individual, a lab group, a department, an institution, or an international community. SciGaP will help train a new generation of cyberinfrastructure developers in open source development, providing these early career developers with the ability to make publicly documented contributions to gateway software and to bridge the gap between academic and non-academic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of the UltraScan Science Gateway was one of the projects of the OGCE SciGaP project. It served multiple purposes. On the one hand, the needs of the UltraScan community helped to define the requirements for a general, flexible and fast grid middleware system that has unique and challenging requirements. As such, the UltraScan project was used as a representative use case for a demanding Science Gateway with a broad range of features, functionalities and requirements, and helped guide the design of the Apache Airavata software. Unique challenges brought by the UltraScan software project were abstracted and are now offered to other science gateway in a comprehensive application programming interface that can be readily adapted to other challenging science domains.

On the other hand, the development of the UltraScan Science Gateway provides now an exceptional benefit and value for practitioners of analytical ultracentrifugation, a sophisticated biophysical analysis technique, by abstracting arcane biophysical methods, tedious Linux supercomputer submissions and authentications, and management of extremely large datasets within a deceptively simple web submission system that is easily and quickly learned, even by a technician with only rudimentary computer knowledge and minimal biophysical training. The outcome of this research has accelerated biophysical research in biochemistry, biomedical applications, material science, nanoscience, and synthetic polymer chemistry.

From a user's perspective, the developed software allows a practitioner to easily analyze large, multi-wavelength analytical ultracentrifugation experiments on XSEDE supercomputers by simply selecting an experiment from a list on a website, selecting analysis methods and parameters and clicking "Submit". Once the analysis is submitted, the user can readily monitor experiments that are submitted, queued, running or finished in real-time on another web page. Once completed, the user receives an e-mail notification that the analysis is available for visualization in the UltraScan desktop software. Furthermore, all analyses can be performed in parallel, enhancing throughput by several orders of magnitude, and reducing the analysis of even extremely challenging experimental systems to a few mouse clicks and reducing the required time for analysis from weeks to minutes. The software also provides detailed error reports and monitoring so users can easily detect problems with their data. The system is very robust and is now adopted world-wide with servers in the US, Canada, Germany, Finland, India and Australia, serving well over one hundred institutions world wide.
